Posts.EditableText: Hello everyone, I was wondering if there is a way to find the source code for games. Is there a way to view it? I would like to find the source code for one of the games I have played, but I don't see a way of doing that.W
Posts.HTML: Hello everyone, I was wondering if there is a way to find the source code for games. Is there a way to view it? I would like to find the source code for one of the games I have played, but I don't see a way of doing that.W

Posts.EditableText:
2 ways...  or more...
1) Notepad ++… But, this will list all the code that Quest adds in to make it run... AND takes out the ability to cee the code in the UI... (My question would be "WHY???!!!"
2) load it in Quest, then use the code view... (But same problem as Notepad…)
#3) If you see game.quest… you are looking at the compiled version...
Just make a copy, so that you don't accidently change the original, change game.quest to game.zip, and un-zip it for a new folder...
 Then look at the game.aslx, but... you still have the problem like 1, and 2 above...
Option 4: ask the author for the source code and get the .aslx code without all the code that quest adds...
(OK, so that's 4 not 2... Oh, well…)
Posts.HTML:
2 ways... or more...

  1. Notepad ++… But, this will list all the code that Quest adds in to make it run... AND takes out the ability to cee the code in the UI... (My question would be "WHY???!!!"
  2. load it in Quest, then use the code view... (But same problem as Notepad…)
    #3) If you see game.quest… you are looking at the compiled version...
    Just make a copy, so that you don't accidently change the original, change game.quest to game.zip, and un-zip it for a new folder...
    Then look at the game.aslx, but... you still have the problem like 1, and 2 above...
    Option 4: ask the author for the source code and get the .aslx code without all the code that quest adds...
    (OK, so that's 4 not 2... Oh, well…)
